content.description: Easy moves up the slippery apron lead to a pod and small roof. Lieback past with slippery feet, then nice stemming above in double cracks leads to the big ledge. Above, choose your favorite of the several exit cracks. There are several loose blocks just below the lip of the big ledge, but these seemed "keyed in." I futzed with them for a while but couldn't make any of them come out. Bomber!
content.protection: Cams from #00 TCU through #2 Camalot, single set is fine. And a set of smaller nuts. Tree for anchor.
content.location: The left most of the Three Yogis.

content.description: Hopping is the middle of the slippery Yogi Cracks. A really slick start puts you up in the right-facing corner and straight-forward climbing until you get to a right-arching finger crack section that leads to a big ledge. The crux of the route is the finger section, but you can face climb out of it to reach the ledge. Then move left and climb up via a pair of cracks leading to the rim.
content.protection: Rack nuts and 00 TCU up to #2 Camalot size. Emphasis on the small to medium cams.
content.location: Middle of the three Yogi Cracks.

content.description: Dancing is the rightmost Yogi Crack. It's probably offers a marginally less amount of slick rock. Climb up the "apron" to reach a sort of overhanging tight-hands crack. Pull over the corner at the top onto a good ledge. A steep hands crack leadst to the rim from there.
content.location: Right of the three Yogi Cracks. See photo on the main page for the Yogi area.

content.description:
The Yogi Crack Area is the sort of small ampitheater west and above the Gold Wall on the north side of the canyon end. The Yogi Cracks are a set of three similar crack routes that feature slippery rock and tricky protection in places. In general, the cracks get harder as they go from left (9-) to right (9+). 

  This area is popular with climbers looking for moderate lines. Take care here as the slippery rock and tricky protection has caused severe accidents (including one fatality) in the past.
